Interesting though. Long may it continue.

Posts.Title: Has anyone had a CT scan before diagnosis?

Posts.Content: Little wombat Sorry it had to come to that for you, but hopefully it's given everyone the wake up call they need and they will be more supportive and helpful from now on. You've brought back a couple of memories for me. When I first started working, I was in a typing pool and every Christmas one of the gentlemen on another floor bought us a box of Toffifee, which I believe I have seen in B&M bargains if you have one near you. Also all my childhood holidays were spent in Bournemouth and I have very fond memories of those times, so thank you for that
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: I am, that's for ovarian. "CA15-3 is used as a tumour marker to monitor a patient's response to breast cancer treatment." They test for it when you have a blood test, well it's been on my blood work forms before and I looked it up. Although I've never been given any results or numbers so can't help there.
Posts.Title: Blood test for 'markers'

Posts.Content: Thanks for that. Much more professionally done than my reply!
Posts.Title: Blood test for 'markers'

Posts.Content: Hi everyone Little wombat I understand where you're coming from about your daughter. I have, for a long time, had a semi strained relationship with my eldest daughter.   In the kitchen the other day she banged her head on a cupboard door, I automatically went to give her a cuddle, immediately I get "Mum, you know I don't like being touched". I was having a 'scared it might come back day' and promptly burst into tears. Then everything is such a drama with me, er excuse me?! I only finished my treatment 6 weeks ago, I think I'm entitled to feel a little raw now and again. I explained that I was feeling a bit scared and the response was "you don't have cancer now".  Basically, it's over now, get on with it. We ended up having a huge row about her insensitivity and lack of understanding, apparently it's all a bit much for her. I have tried so hard not to bother anyone with how I feel now that my treatment has finished, and even through my treatment you do your best to shield your family as best you can. Sorry, rambling, based on experiences with my daughter, I've found the best way is to just let her get on with it. I find if I keep saying I'm sorry for whatever it is I'm supposed to have done, it seems to her that she is fully justified in her actions. Don't apologise for keeping it from her, you had your reasons, (obviously you wanted to protect her until you knew what was what). I'm just completely normal with her, I get the cold shoulder for a couple of days and then she starts speaking again. I don't bring up what happened.   Apparently she's still waiting for an apology from when I asked her to get some lemons for me and she asked for the £1.80, I told her I thought she had a nerve as she lives here rent free and any money she gets is her own. According to her I was rubbing her nose in the fact that she doesn't have much money. I told her she will be waiting a long time for that apology, i.e. never. By the way she is 25, gets £500 a month, is using it to pay debts off, which is why we are not charging her board as I hope the sooner she gets it paid off, the sooner she will be able to have her own place again. Not sure this will be at all helpful, just wanted you to know that I understand where you're coming from.
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi JustLittleMe I've just had to look up what a diep reconstruction is! I didn't have that. They used my right boob to reconstruct the left as I was quite big and didn't mind going smaller. I haven't had any tissue used from anywhere else. Hope that makes sense

Posts.Title: petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

Posts.Content: I've got mine next Tuesday (7th). My boobs are still quite tender which I didn't think they would be now as it's a year on Friday since my op. I can understand the left as that's the one that had all the treatment, but I expected the right one to be okay as it was done to match. I'm worried it will be painful, but agree it has to be done.
Posts.Title: One Year On !!

Posts.Content: I asked about genetic testing when I got diagnosed as I have 2 grown up daughters and was told 'no' as there is no history in my family. I would have still liked to know though for their sake and I still would. I'm going to ask at my April appointment. Just because there's no history doesn't mean that my daughters won't get BC, it just means I'm the first and the history starts with me.

Posts.Title: Repeat eyetests

Posts.Content: I also used the gel/cream for the first time yesterday. I agree with Kerry, it felt lovely and my boob feels very moisturised.  I didn't mention it to the radiographer as I also trust the reviews I have read from other ladies that it has been successful for. Out of interest Kerry, how many sessions do you have left? We seem to be running in a bit of a tandem at the moment with R1/2, although you are a bit ahead of me on the aspirin trial, I start the run in next Tuesday.  I'm in Nottingham so not to far from you. Keep up the good work everyone
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Hi everyone After reading these posts, I have put a call in to my doctor to see if I can get a prescription for R1 and R2. I too am worried about burns as I am very fair. I've just started my second week of rads and would feel much happier knowing that I am using something that has been so effective for other ladies. Hopefully I haven't left it too late for it to make a difference. Anyway fingers crossed for a sympathetic doctor calling me back. It's just the constant worry of 'what if' regarding my skin and makes me feel quite anxious sometimes, even though the treatment itself is pretty easy and I am very lucky to only have a 10 minute drive to the hospital. Will let you know how I get on.
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Hi I picked up my R1 & 2 today.  I know it says to apply the R1 after the radiotherapy session, does that mean that you don't apply it at the weekend, but just use the R2 or don't use them at all?  Also my doctor has given me 180 sachets of R1 and 56 sachets of R2, I only have 14 sessions left.  I don't want them to go to waste, but am unsure of what, if anything, I can do with them.  I would be happy to donate them, but am not if this is something that would be possible or be able to be accepted.
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Thanks guys for the replies and advice. I'll take a sachet to the hospital with me, so I can apply as soon as I'm finished. It's good to know that I can offer any 'leftovers' as it's not prescription only.
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Hi just read the reply to Ali, looks like my doctor got it the wrong way round! I have 180 sachets of R1 and 56 R2, but since surgery I am now 3 cups smaller so have plenty. If anyone needs any more R1, please give me a shout. I also fibbed to my doctor and said the radiographer had recommended it, oops! Kerry - I have had 10 rads, 5 more to go, then 8 booster.
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Got a call back from my doctor and told her what I wanted. She said she'd never heard of it and asked me to go down to the surgery.  When I got there she had a prescription for R1 and R2 ready and waiting for me, including a print out of the instructions on how to use it! Also found out that I've got an ear infection so a prescription for that as well.  My local pharmacy said I can pick the creams up on Thursday, really pleased. A big thank you for all the posts on this, otherwise I would have been none the wiser

Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: Hi karen20 I also had bad diarrhoea with T, but no cramps.  My oncologist prescribed loperamide, which is the same as the over the counter anti diarrhoea tablets.  She said that she didn't want me losing too many minerals etc which you do with diarrhoea. You don't seem to have been given much help, I think it's awful you've just been left to it.  Perhaps your gp would be willing to give you a prescription for loperamide, if not, boots sell diarrhoea relief tablets. I hope you start to feel better soon.
Posts.Title: overactive bowel

Posts.Content: Hi everyone  When I was first diagnosed my sister sent me a copy of the China Study, she had read it already and scared me to death with stories of how whatever I was eating would bring about a recurrence.  When I was first diagnosed I went into complete headless chicken mode, googling everything, buying various lotions, potions, books, food, whatever, convinced that I must do or follow a certain way otherwise the worst would happen. Obviously as time went on and I learnt to live with what was happening and started my treatment plan, I calmed down and was able to be more rational about things. I have made changes to my diet, cut down on diary, red meat, sugary things and increased fruit, veg, fish, but that was mainly because I have been recently diagnosed with familial high cholesterol, which I am starting treatment for at the end of November (oh goody!). I assume I will be put on statins which opens up another cans of worms as I know there is evidence that they are not that good for you, but there is also evidence that they can prevent recurrence of BC. Decision for another day. I even bought Professor Plant's book, which I found interesting, but I don't know, I guess it was too strict for me. I just don't want to go through life not having things I enjoy just in case my cancer comes back.  I agree with Julia's nan, a little bit of what you fancy...
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi I have something exactly the same as that roughly 4 or 5 inches above the centre of my cleavage. It feels smooth, is about 3-4mm (if that), itches very occasionally. I've had it about 6 weeks. Spoke to my GP who didn't think it was anything, but told me to keep my eye on it. It hasn't changed at all. I thought it was a spot or bite to start with, but after various bombardments with creams etc, it's still there.  I personally know that it's not anything as I had a ct scan 2 weeks ago on chest, abdomen etc, so if it was something it would have been picked up. Sorry I'm waffling, should be asleep. Anyway what I'm trying to say is, it doesn't matter what I say, it doesn't matter what anybody on here says. You have to see somone whose decision you trust and find out one way or the other. You are making yourself ill, you need to get it sorted. Waiting for results is crap, but at least you will know. There is no point second guessing. Insist on seeing who you want and insist on getting tests/biopsy/whatever carried out on it. We all feel for you hon and we are all here for you. Next time I shall be wanting to hear about definitive results. Come on, you can do it, we are all behind you. Feel the fear and do it anyway. I shall be telling myself that as my chemo starts on the 30th and I'm scared sh*tless. Lots of love to you

Posts.Title: Your cancer wasn't bad then....

Posts.Content: Hi Edwina Just a thought on the steroids. Chemo unit told me to take my last lot no later than 1.00 pm as they can cause weird dreams. I used to take mine at 8 am and midday and found that worked pretty well for me. Obviously you may take your tablets at these times anyway, but if not, thought it might be worth mentioning Love the knitting.
Posts.Title: 1st chemo session yesterday!!

Posts.Content: Hi Edwina Just a thought on the steroids. Chemo unit told me to take my last lot no later than 1.00 pm as they can cause weird dreams. Posts.Title: 1st chemo session yesterday!!

Posts.Content: Hi Islanikita  I haven't had a mastectomy either, but just wanted to say that you are absolutely not a freak. Lots of ladies have big boobs and in my opinion it should be the hospital's job to make sure that all sizes are catered for.  The operation would be hard enough without having to feel that there is something wrong with you, just because they don't have a softie in your size and if they have limited suppliers for the prosthesis, so what?! You need it in that size and that's all there is to it. Please don't be too hard on yourself, your family love you for you, not your boobs. Big hugs to you.
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: xx
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi I have literally just been checking my boobs and am convinced I can feel 2 lumps in my 'bad' boob, but again only when I'm sitting up not lying down. Not sure about the technical terms, but one on the inner quadrant and one where my tumour was on the other side. I have finished chemo and am on rads. Would the side I was operated on tend to feel more lumpy than the other one? I know they take images during radiotherapy, would this show anything up? I feel like I'm overreacting and am a bit in headless chicken mode at the moment.
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: Thanks for your replies, good to know that lumps and bumps are to be expected in the operated on boob. Will ring my BCN in the morning and see what she suggests.  Feeling a lot calmer now, this site is a godsend. Thank you again.
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: I have watery eyes as well. They run constantly and get all dry and crusty in the corners. I know, I know, just can't help getting all the attractive features!! My lovely GP gave me eye drops and they really help. I put mine down to chemo as I don't suffer from hay fever.
Posts.Title: 3.5 weeks post chemo - watery eye

Posts.Content: Hi Maria I know exactly what you mean, I was watching Chicago Med the other night and there was this woman, looking like a skeleton in a headscarf being wheeled out of the hospital, the next minute we're at her funeral! I was bawling my eyes out and continued to do so for quite a while, imagining all sorts of horrid scenarios for myself.  I can relate to how you feel about your hair, I was exactly the same, I think most of us are, all I can say that for me the thinking about it going was much more stressful than when it actually went.  To be honest my scalp was so unbearably painful I was glad to get it shaved off. No, it's not nice, but like everything else it's doable. I finished my chemo in June and now have a full covering of hair, albeit short. I saw a lady at the hospital yesterday, wearing a turban and she just thought that I just had short hair and was very excited to learn that it was only 3 months growth. I could see her thinking hmm that could be me 3 months after I finish.  We all think we're never going to get there but we do, good days, bad days and in between days. I think we need the sobbing days, horrible though they are, to release some of the stress and fears that we feel. It's just another way of coping and processing what is happening to us and never feel that you are less than strong because you feel like this. Hope you get your heating fixed quickly
Posts.Title: I think the poop has hit the fan

Posts.Content: She is. She's so supportive, reading some of the stories on here, I feel lucky to have her.
Posts.Title: Job lot

Posts.Content: Hi everyone Just dropping in to say that I had my first mammogram yesterday. I was really worried about it being painful, but the lady was lovely, she said not to suffer and to let her know. The right one was okay, just a few seconds of gritted teeth. The left was more painful, but when I said that was as far as I could go on the pain front, she said that it would be fine and left it there. So all in all not too bad, now just the wait! Also had my first eye test since chemo (finished last June) and my eyes haven't changed at all, which means no change in 3 years and I didn't have to pay! So pretty pleased with that as well. Sending lots of love to everyone. Edit: My lovely BCN has just rung me to say my results are back and it's all clear, she didn't want me to have to wait and be worrying. What a star! Not a bad couple of days
